mxCell.value:
MasterListener

Central coordinator (“conductor / traffic controller”) for all socket-level activity.

Responsibilities:
  • Creates and manages Listener objects

  • Binds listening sockets

  • Accepts new client connections

  • Registers all listening sockets with poll()

  • Dispatches accepted client sockets to the ConnectionManager

  • Coordinates communication with response worker processes via pipes

Holds:

  • std::vector<pollfd> _pollFds
    Complete set of file descriptors currently monitored by poll()

  • std::map<int, Listener*> _listeners
    Listening socket fd → owning Listener

  • std::map<int, Listener*> _clientListeners
    Client socket fd → Listener that accepted it

  • std::map<int, int> _responseWorkerControls
    Pipe read-end fd → client socket fd
    (Used to receive control messages from response workers)

  • std::map<int, int> _responseWorkers
    Pipe read-end fd → client socket fd
    (Used to receive generated HTTP responses from response workers)

Listener

Protocol owner / connection manager for a single server endpoint.

  • Creates a listening socket
    (socket(), bind(), listen())

  • Represents exactly one endpoint
    Bound to a single interface:port pair

  • Accepts and manages all client connections
    Belonging to this endpoint (same server block)

  • Owns the HTTP protocol flow for its clients
    Request reception, response generation, and sending

    Owns:

    • Listening socket file descriptor
      int _listeningSocketFd

    • Active client connections
      std::map<int, Connection*> _clientConnections
      (client socket fd → Connection)

    • Endpoint configuration
      const Endpoint& _configuration

server {
listen 8080;
server_name localhost;

root ./www;

error_page 404 /errors/404.html;

location / {
root ./www;
index index.html;
autoindex off;
}

location /images {
root ./assets/images;
}

location /upload {
allowed_methods POST;
upload_store ./uploads;
}
}

AppConfig
Central configuration container for the webserver; parses the config file and exposes all server-level configuration.

Holds:

  • A set of Endpoint objects (unique interface + port pairs)

Endpoint
Represents a single server endpoint bound to one network interface and port; defines how requests on that socket are handled.

Holds:

  • Network binding (interface, port)

  • Server identity (serverName)

  • Root directory for request resolution

  • Maximum allowed request body size

  • Route definitions (RouteConfig)

  • CGI handlers mapped by file extension

  • Upload configuration

  • Validation rules for port ranges

HttpRequestHandler

serves static files / CGI / directory listing

Connection

Single-client protocol handler.

A Connection represents one client socket and is responsible for all I/O and protocol state associated with that client.

Responsibilities:

  • Owns the client socket file descriptor

  • Reads from the client socket
    (request reception and parsing)

  • Writes to the client socket
    (sending generated responses)

  • Maintains protocol state
    (Connection::State)

WebServer → manages config, listeners, signal-handling
↓
MasterListener → binds sockets, accepts new connections
↓
ConnectionHandler → reads/writes to a single client
↓
RequestParser → turns raw text into HttpRequest
↓
Router → selects correct server/location block
↓
RequestHandler → static files / CGI / directory listing
↓
ResponseBuilder → builds HttpResponse
↓
HttpResponse::toString() → send back to client

GETHandler

Purpose: Retrieve a resource.
Requests data from the server.
Has no body (normally).
Should not modify anything on the
server.
Typical use: serving HTML, images,
CSS, files.

POSTHandler

Purpose: Send data to the server.
Used to submit forms, upload files, send JSON, etc.
Has a request body (often
required).
Can create or modify resources
depending on server logic.

DELETEHandler
Purpose: Delete a resource on the server. 
Tells the server to remove the specified file or object. 
 Dangerous — must be explicitly allowed. 
Server decides what “delete” means; not always supported.

HttpRequest 
Parser

Parses the incoming HTTP requests, breaks it
into:
0) method
1) start line
2) request headers
3) request body

WebServer

Singleton responsible for managing the lifetime and global state of the web server.


Holds:

_appConfig

Parsed webserv configuration.

_masterListener

Owns and coordinates all listening sockets and incoming connection handling.

_isRunning

Atomic flag indicating the current server state, used to control the main loop and trigger graceful shutdown.

Request

Each request contains:
start line
response headers
/r/n/r/n
response body

Response

The class responsible for building the server response.
Each response contains:

1) start line
2) response headers
/r/n/r/n
3) response body

MasterListener
→ creates N Listener objects
→ each Listener creates a Listening Socket (bind, listen)
→ adds all Listening Sockets to poll()
→ poll() indicates that Listener X has a connection
→ MasterListener calls accept() on that Listening Socket
→ OS returns new Client Socket (unique fd)
→ MasterListener hands Client Socket to ConnectionManager
→ HTTP I/O happens on Client Socket

Listening socket

ONE listening socket binds to ONE
endpoint
Client socket #2
Client socket #1
Client socket #n
Listener #n
1xx: Info 2xx: Success 3xx: Redirection 4xx: Client error 5xx: Server error

single client

ConnectionHandler → reads/writes to a
single client

ConnectionHandler → reads/writes to a
single client
HTTP Status
Parsing
One ENDPOINT = One LISTENING SOCKET
config file

Listening socket
the webserver's door

(one per Listener, i.e. per interface:port)
